attributes.title: Comparative US Media Coverage of Soviet and Chinese Space Programs, 1957–2019

q1.value: Comparative US Media Coverage of Soviet and Chinese Space Programs, 1957–2019

q5.value: With thanks to Ken Benoit, Alexander Cooley, Don Green, Hanzhang Liu, Andrew Nathan, Cheryl Schonhardt-Bailey, Arthur Spirling, Georgiy Syunaev, and participants at the 2019 Harriman-IMEMO Conference in Moscow for helpful feedback.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Public opinion polling data shows that US public opinion toward space activity, including geopolitical adversary space activity, has historically been quite favorable. This is surprising given the incentives governments have to gin up foreign threats in order to raise support for costly space programs. By integrating observational text analysis with a randomized survey experiment, this study will investigate the role of news media in shaping public attitudes across time.

q16.value: Q1: Do readers perceive adversary space programs more favorably when exposed to positive coverage, and more critically when exposed to negative coverage? • H 1 : valence (weakly) correlates with article sentiment, but the effect for negative articles should be lower. This question examines the power of the media “messenger” to move reader attitudes by varying how an article is framed. The next question measures the magnitude of inherent preferences for neutral space activity over adversary space activity. Q2: Do readers perceive adversary space programs more negatively than neutral programs? • H 2 : readers tend to perceive adversary space activity less favorably than neutral activity. The last question asks whether differences observed in RQ1 and RQ2, if any, are driven by (a) within-article framing or (b) prior preferences shaped by knowledge or events external to the experimental context. Q3: Does reader sentiment differ between adversary space programs, holding article content constant? • H 3A : readers tend to favor Chinese programs over Russian programs. (This might suggest that readers are influenced more by a durable Cold War “space race” memory than current events spillover, such as the US-China technology and trade war.) • H 3B : readers tend to favor Russian programs over Chinese programs. (This might suggest that readers are influenced more by current events spillover than Cold War memory.) Q4: how reliable was the sentiment analysis coding scheme used to identify positive/negative articles for use in the vignettes? -N/A

q17.value: • H 1 is tested by randomizing exposure to a highly “positive” article or a highly “negative” article (pre-coded by a sentiment analysis algorithm). • H 2 is tested by randomizing country name attribution in the article to a US adversary (China, Russia) or a neutral country (India). • H 3 will be tested using subgroup analysis between the Russia and China treatment groups. • Q4 will be answered by comparing the overall mean from the sentiment analysis results with the overall mean of the subject pool and testing for statistical significance.

registration_responses.q1: Comparative US Media Coverage of Soviet and Chinese Space Programs, 1957–2019
registration_responses.q5: With thanks to Ken Benoit, Alexander Cooley, Don Green, Hanzhang Liu, Andrew Nathan, Cheryl Schonhardt-Bailey, Arthur Spirling, Georgiy Syunaev, and participants at the 2019 Harriman-IMEMO Conference in Moscow for helpful feedback.

attributes.title: Estimating the effect of LinkNYC on voter registration and participation

q1.value: Estimating the effect of LinkNYC on voter registration and participation

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Beginning in 2015, New York City began installing LinkNYC kiosks to replace the city’s network of payphones. Each kiosk features 55’’ high definition displays that show content including advertising and transit information, as well as tablets for accessing city services and maps, free USB charging stations, and phones for making domestic calls. On September 21st, 2018, LinkNYC launched a voter registration drive to encourage voter registration on kiosk tablets, which connect users to an electronic voter registration page. While these devices are designed to bring internet access and city services to users’ fingertips, their ability to promote electoral participation is an open question; their usage for this purpose – and whether messages encouraging participation actually work – has not been studied. An important question is whether increasing access to, and the visibility of, voter registration resources improves electoral participation. The present study is a randomized implementation of registration encouragement using LinkNYC large screens to display either (1) a localized neighborhood-identity based participation appeal; (2) an urgency appeal; or (3) no appeal (a control group). Randomization occurs at the Census tract level (n = 828). Outcomes measured include individual counts of voter registration site usage, with date-times, duration of use, and location of specific kiosks where each use occurred, as well as voter registration and turnout data. From 9/21/18 through 10/12/18 (registration deadline), all kiosks in a given census tract will display their assigned message, or lack of a message, at regular intervals, alongside other usual (non-experimental) content. At the end of that period, the implementing organization (CityBridge LLC, which operates the kiosks) will provide timestamped counts of registrations on each kiosk during the study period. Although we will not have information about individual registrants, we use the NYC voter file to obtain characteristics of people who registered during the study period under each of the three conditions based on the census tract in which they live and the kiosks nearest their home address.

q16.value: Outcomes are measured from two main sources: (1) counts of individuals who use LinkNYC kiosks to register at the kiosk level, provided by CityBridge, which can be aggregated up to the tract level, and (2) voter information from the NYC voter file. The former includes date and time information, while the latter includes dates, allowing us to determine which registrations occurred during the message campaign and to study heterogeneous effects by proximity to the registration deadline. Moreover, we will obtain an updated NYC voter file after Election Day to determine whether those who registered after exposure to the interventions actually turned out to vote. Though we will be unable to identity which individuals registered on a LinkNYC kiosk, since treatment is randomized at the tract level we can treat all registrants in a tract as having been treated to some degree (i.e., it is plausible that individuals saw the ads and subsequently registered via another medium). The following hypotheses will be tested with data from both sources unless otherwise specified. H1: Encouragement effect: Registration will be higher in tracts where the messages are shown compared to those in which they were not shown. H2: Neighborhood-specific vs. countdown message: We will test the efficacy of two different messages. The first appeals to neighborhood identity (e.g., “Greenpoint added XXX new voters in 2017. Tap ‘register now’ on the tablet to join in” ) and the second shows a dynamic countdown to the registration deadline (“06 days 04 hours 22 seconds until the voter registration deadline for the November general elections. Tap ‘register now’ on the tablet to join in”). H3: Heterogeneous effects: Subject to sample size constraints, we plan to explore the possibility of heterogeneous treatment effects by attributes of individuals’ context, as well as by individual characteristics. Are the effect of the messages moderated by local racial or socioeconomic context, or by individual characteristics? Since the literature is largely silent on these effects with respect to voter registration, this exercise is largely exploratory. See pre-analysis plan for details. H4: Subsequent voting: How likely to vote are people who registered during the messaging campaign in treated tracts vs. those who registered in control tracts? Are people who were exposed to the neighborhood identity message vs. the countdown message more or less likely to vote?

q17.value: The main outcome variable is the tract level registration rate, calculated as the number of new registrants divided by the number of people eligible to register. The numerator comes from either the number of people who register at LinkNYC kiosks, or from the number of people who register via any method, during the study period. Subject to data availability we also calculate a registration rate out of the typical number of sessions on each kiosk per day. H1: Encouragement effect: We conduct t-tests of the difference in means of the tract-level registration rate in treatment tracts (pooled) vs. control tracts. We also run OLS regressions controlling for pre-treatment registration rates, which we were unable to block on, as well as poverty status, educational attainment, age distribution, residential mobility, homeownership, and employment, in order to increase precision. In order to account for upward trending registration rates as the election approaches, we will calculate the difference-in-differences from the NYC voter file: (registration rate in treatment tracts at t0 - registration rate in control tracts at t0) - (registration rate in treatment tracts at t1 - registration rate in control tracts at t1), where t0 includes the 22 days prior to 9/21 and t1 includes 9/21 – 10/12 (same number of days in t0 and t1). H2: Neighborhood-specific vs. countdown message: We will regress tract level registration rates on indicators for which type of message was received as well as the controls described above. H3: Heterogeneous effects: See pre-analysis plan for details. H4: Subsequent voting: We regress an indicator for whether the individual voted on tract-level treatment indicators and controls for individual characteristics (race, age, gender) and contextual variables, clustering standard errors at the tract level.

q19.value: The experiment will involve 838 Census tracts

attributes.title: Clientelist Candidates and Voting Behavior in Brazil

q1.value: Clientelist Candidates and Voting Behavior in Brazil

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The objective of the study is to investigate how voters process, react to, and act on information about political candidates engaging in clientelist or other types of particularist behavior. How does hearing about a candidate's use of particularist appeals affect voters' likelihood of voting for the candidate? How do the details of a clientelist exchanges affect how people view the exchange's moral or legal acceptability?

q16.value: H1: Voters have an aversion toward quid-pro-quo particularist benefits (clientelism). H2: Voters have a preference for public goods over private ones. H3: Voters are more supportive of candidates when they live near the candidate's base of support. Voters who live near a candidate’s electoral base will also be more supportive of their particularist behavior. Experiment 2: Voters judge potentially clientelist exchanges as more unethical and illegal if … - H1: the politician requires a quid-pro-quo exchange from the potential recipient. - H2: the politician offers the benefit directly to an individual voter rather than to a community leader. - H3: the recipient changes their vote as a result of the benefit. - H4: the recipient is wealthy. - H5: the politician offers cash or material goods rather than services or a job.

q17.value: The research will involve a survey with 2000 Brazilian voters that includes two conjoint experiments. In the first, respondents will be shown profiles of two hypothetical political candidates and asked to say which one they would be more likely to vote for. I will randomly vary the candidates’ particularist behavior to test the main hypotheses. In the second conjoint, respondents will read a vignette of a situation that “occasionally occurs” during elections in Brazil. The vignettes will describe a politician offering some benefit to a voter or group of voters, with different details of the exchange randomly varied. Respondents will be asked to rate the ethicality and legality of the politician’s behavior and asked to say what the voter should do in response to the offer.

Respondents will be asked to rate the ethicality and legality of the politician’s behavior and asked to say what the voter should do in response to the offer.

attributes.title: Can policy signals break the corruption equilibrium? Court effectiveness and popular engagement against corruption in Tunisia and South Africa

q1.value: Can policy signals break the corruption equilibrium? Court effectiveness and popular engagement against corruption in Tunisia and South Africa

q2.value: Letícia Barbabela | Miquel Pellicer | Eva Wegner

q5.value: Data for the survey experiment examined in this project were collected through DFG grant PE 2423/3-1.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This paper studies the extent to which the sanctioning of corrupt officials by the courts might signal government effectiveness against corruption. Citizens in corrupt countries loathe corruption and acknowledge its pervasiveness but return corrupt politicians into office, continue to pay bribes and generally refrain from reporting corruption (Cábelková and Hanousek 2004; Manzetti and Wilson 2008; Zechmeister and Zizumbo-Colunga 2013; Chong et al. 2015; Pereira and Mello 2015; Fernandez-Vazquez et al. 2016; Corbacho et al. 2016). A compelling explanation for why corruption is so persistent is given by scholars that frame it as a collective action problem (Persson et al 2013; Rothstein 2011; Johnston 2014; Mungiu-Pippidi 2006). Although widespread corruption may demobilize citizens (Kostadinova 2009; Chong et al 2014; Bauhr and Grimes 2014) and depress trust in institutions (Anderson and Tverdova 2003; Bowler and Karp 2004; Warren 2004; Seligson 2006; Hakhverdian and Mayne 2015, Seligson 2002, Mishler and Rose 2001), there is evidence that perceptions of government effectiveness can lead to anti-corruption activism (Peiffer and Alvarez 2016), even in high-corruption equilibrium countries. Before this background, this paper proposes a mechanism starts from the way courts perform in analyzing a corruption case. Courts display positive or negative signals through their performance but how citizens perceive this also depends on the specific corruption case. In terms of performance, efficiency, impartiality, and effectiveness are regarded as positive outcomes. The better the courts perform, the more it will be expected to foster engagement against corruption. Regarding the characteristics of the case, the status of the public official (high or low ranking) implicated in the corruption case moderates the magnitude of the signals of court performance. Ultimately, effective corruption sanctioning influences attitudes towards corruption through the channels of trust in courts and citizens’ efficacy, by addressing expectations about impunity.

q16.value: The main outcome variables are “acceptability to pay bribes”, “support anti-corruption policies”, and “engagement against corruption”. There are four main hypotheses, subdivided into sub- hypotheses: H1: Court effectiveness in analyzing corruption cases fosters citizens’ engagement against corruption. H2: The characteristics of the corruption case, conveyed by the defendants’ ranking, shape the magnitude and the type of engagement against corruption, but less so than courts’ performance H3: Court effectiveness operates through the channels of trust in courts and citizens’ efficacy by decreasing expectations about impunity; H4: Trust, sense of efficacy, the salience of corruption, proneness to strategically use corruption and personality traits mediate the extent to which the mechanism works.

q17.value: We use a conjoint experiment where respondents are read a vignette describing a fictional court investigation. There are three components in the vignette that vary: the defendant’s ranking, court efficiency and court impartiality. Subsequently to the vignette, respondents are asked questions that serve as manipulation checks, account for the channels in the mechanism and serve as outcome variables. We test the hypotheses with standard OLS regressions of the outcome variable on indicator variables of efficiency, impartiality and defendant’s ranking. When relevant, we interact these indicator variables with pre-treatment variables.

q19.value: 1,200 in Tunisia and 1,000 in South Africa.

q27.value: In South Africa, data collection is implemented by Citizen Surveys and in Tunisia, by ELKA consulting.

registration_responses.q5: Data for the survey experiment examined in this project were collected through DFG grant PE 2423/3-1.

registration_responses.q27: In South Africa, data collection is implemented by Citizen Surveys and in Tunisia, by ELKA consulting.

q2.value: Donald Green | Casey Libonate | Michael G. Miller

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Within a large introduction to American Politics class, we randomly assign students in 18 discussion sections to participate in a moderated conversation with either a Democratic or Republican party chairman, or an attorney via Skype. In a three-wave survey conducted within the class, we will examine how these conversations shaped students’ views of both their party and the opposite party.

q16.value: Quantities of interest are described in greater detail in the attached pre-analysis plan. Hypotheses are as follows: Among Democratic and Republican respondents, relative to control, exposure to a conversation with an out-party elite: 1. Will cause a more positive shift in feeling thermometer of respondent’s out-party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 2. Will cause respondents to position the Republican and Democratic Parties more closely (in absolute terms) on the feeling thermometers in Wave 2 than in Wave 1. 3. Will cause a stronger negative shift in out-party social distance from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 4. Will cause a more positive shift in positive descriptor index of respondent’s out-party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 5. Will cause no change in feeling thermometer of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). 6. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). 7. Will cause no change in trust of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). Among independent and third-party respondents, relative to control, exposure to a conversation with a party elite: 8. Will cause a more positive shift in feeling thermometer of the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 9. Will cause respondents to position the Republican and Democratic Parties more closely (in absolute terms) on the feeling thermometers in Wave 2 than in Wave 1. 10. Will cause a stronger negative shift in social distance from the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 11. Will cause a more positive shift in positive descriptor index of the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 12. Will cause no change in feeling thermometer of the party opposite that of the party elite from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two tailed). 13. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of the party opposite that of the party elite from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). 14. Will cause no change in trust of the party opposite the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). Among Democratic and Republican respondents, relative to control, exposure to a conversation with an out-party elite: 1. Will cause no change in feeling thermometer of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 2. Will cause no shift in feeling thermometer of respondent’s out-party from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 3. Will cause no change in the manner in which respondents position the Republican and Democratic Parties on the feeling thermometers in Wave 3 than in Wave 1. 4. Will cause no shift in out-party social distance from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 5. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 6. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of respondent’s out-party from Wave 1 to Wave Among independent and third-party respondents, relative to control, exposure to a conversation with a party elite: 7. Will cause no change in feeling thermometer of the party opposite that of the party elite from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 8. Will cause no shift in feeling thermometer of the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 9. Will cause no shift in the manner in which respondents position the Republican and Democratic Parties on the feeling thermometers in Wave 3 than in Wave 1. 10. Will cause no shift in social distance from the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 11. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of the party opposite that of the party elite from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 12. Will cause no shift in positive descriptor index of the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 3.

registration_responses.q2: Donald Green | Casey Libonate | Michael G. Miller
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: Within a large introduction to American Politics class, we randomly assign students in 18 discussion sections to participate in a moderated conversation with either a Democratic or Republican party chairman, or an attorney via Skype. In a three-wave survey conducted within the class, we will examine how these conversations shaped students’ views of both their party and the opposite party.
registration_responses.q16: Quantities of interest are described in greater detail in the attached pre-analysis plan. Hypotheses are as follows: Among Democratic and Republican respondents, relative to control, exposure to a conversation with an out-party elite: 1. Will cause a more positive shift in feeling thermometer of respondent’s out-party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 2. Will cause respondents to position the Republican and Democratic Parties more closely (in absolute terms) on the feeling thermometers in Wave 2 than in Wave 1. 3. Will cause a stronger negative shift in out-party social distance from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 4. Will cause a more positive shift in positive descriptor index of respondent’s out-party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 5. Will cause no change in feeling thermometer of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). 6. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). 7. Will cause no change in trust of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). Among independent and third-party respondents, relative to control, exposure to a conversation with a party elite: 8. Will cause a more positive shift in feeling thermometer of the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 9. Will cause respondents to position the Republican and Democratic Parties more closely (in absolute terms) on the feeling thermometers in Wave 2 than in Wave 1. 10. Will cause a stronger negative shift in social distance from the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 11. Will cause a more positive shift in positive descriptor index of the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 2. 12. Will cause no change in feeling thermometer of the party opposite that of the party elite from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two tailed). 13. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of the party opposite that of the party elite from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). 14. Will cause no change in trust of the party opposite the party elite’s party from Wave 1 to Wave 2 (two-tailed). Among Democratic and Republican respondents, relative to control, exposure to a conversation with an out-party elite: 1. Will cause no change in feeling thermometer of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 2. Will cause no shift in feeling thermometer of respondent’s out-party from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 3. Will cause no change in the manner in which respondents position the Republican and Democratic Parties on the feeling thermometers in Wave 3 than in Wave 1. 4. Will cause no shift in out-party social distance from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 5. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of respondent’s own party from Wave 1 to Wave 3. 6. Will cause no change in positive descriptor index of respondent’s out-party from Wave 1 to Wave Among independent and third-party respondents, relative to control, exposure to a conversation with a party elite: 7. registration_responses.q23: Research is for pedagogical purposes within a class, and is therefore exempt.

q1.value: The Impact of the Educational Support Climate on Adolescent Character, Emotional Development, and Academic Performance

q3.value: There has been considerable research connecting social support to positive outcomes in adolescents (Lerner & Calina, 2014; Bruner, Eys, Wilson, & Côté, 2014; for reviews, see Bianco & Eklund, 2001; Holt & Hoar, 2006; Rees, 2007). However, very few studies have examined the impact of multiple forms of support found in the educational context on the character, emotional development, and performance of adolescence. Increasingly, educators have attempted to determine the role character development plays in the performance outcomes of adolescents, given that both production and character have been linked to long-term positive results (Lerner & Castellino, 2002). The purpose of this study is to examine the impact of the climate of support provided by (parents, teachers, peers) found in educational settings on the character, emotional development, and academic performance of adolescents. Negative outcomes such as stress, depression, dropout rates, and risky behaviors have been associated with disengagement and dissatisfaction from school (Gutiérrez, Tomás, Romero, & Barrica, 2017). While social support from family, teachers, and peers has been associated with greater school engagement and more positive outcomes in adolescents such as better academic performance, life satisfaction and subjective well-being (Lewis, Huebner, Malone, & Valois, 2011; Gilman & Heubner, 2006; Suldo, Shaffer, & Riley, 2008). Results from these studies indicate that further exploration is necessary to determine what aspects of the educational support environment impacts specific elements of character and emotional development and whether there is a difference in performance and character outcomes based on the amount/type of social support received by an adolescent. Teachers and administrators are committed to the success of their students but often lack detailed information into how they can best serve the whole student. Previous studies suggest that by targeting student engagement and well-being, then academic success will follow (Lewis, Huebner, Malone, & Valois, 2011; Lyons & Huebner, 2015; Suldo et al., 2011). Although this is likely an accurate conclusion, it is incomplete in directing school officials on how to improve student engagement and well-being. The results require clarification as to what types of external support are needed to facilitate various form

q4.value:
Students with higher levels of social support will have better well-being than those without social support. Higher levels of social support will be positively related to better academic outcomes.

Athletes will have higher levels of social support compared to non-athletic students. 

Emotion regulation abilities in students will be similar to the emotion regulation abilities of their parents. 

Emotion regulation will mediate the relationship between forms of social support and academic performance and well-being. 

Supportive school climate will be positively related to well-being variables (satisfaction with life, emotion regulation, purpose) and academic performance. A supportive school climate will be negatively related to the pressure to perform.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional survey study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network(CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers. For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer tohttps://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: We expect a sample of more than 1000 participants.

q15.value: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above.

question.value:
1. Satisfaction with life is measured with the Satisfaction with Life Scale. Diener, Emmons, Larsen, and Griffin (1985) developed the Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) to measure global satisfaction with life. 

2. Parental support, both mother and father, will be assessed using a 4-item parental support scale. It is used to assess perceived behaviors from mothers and fathers that communicate to the participant feelings of warmth, affection, and a sense of being valued (Bush, Peterson, Cobas, & Supple, 2002; Henry & Peterson, 1995; Peterson, Rollins, & Thomas, 1985). 

3. Non-parental support (coaches support) was measured with the 16-item Perceived Available Support in Sport Questionnaire (PASS-Q; Freeman, Coffee, & Rees, 2011). 

4. ERQ- Gross and John’s (2003) Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ) will be used to measure individual variation in emotion regulation. 

5. Student Assess Parental ERQ (Mother and Father)
Students will be asked to assess their parents' emotion regulation ability via Gross and John’s (2003) Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ). 

6. Fear of failure appraisal
A Performance Failure Appraisal Inventory (PFAI; Conroy, Willow, Metzler, 2010) will be used to assess the students' fear of failure. 

7. School Climate 
We will assess the quality of participants’ school environments using the following scale:  Student Perceptions of School Cohesion (Arrivallaga et al., 2009). This 10-item scale requires students to rate with a 5-point response scale their perceptions of the school social environment (e.g., “I feel a part of this school”)

8. Pressure to Perform
Participants will rate the degree to which they currently feel pressure to compete in sports and school. Ratings were made on separate 5-point scales (1 = no pressure; 5 = a lot of pressure). 

9. CESD
A screen for depression and other psychological disorders in adolescents (CESD; Garrison, Addy, Jackson, McKeown, Waller, 1991) was used to test for depressive symptoms. 

10. Purpose 
We will examine students' perspectives of purpose using the Claremont Purpose Scale (Bronk, Rcihes, Mangan, 2018). 

11. Performance-based identity scale 

In addition, Character Lab Research Network via the school will collect demographic data including age, gender, ethnicity, grade level, and SES indicators.

In general, models will be run without covariates. We may include demographic variables (e.g., gender, race/ethnicity) as covariates in follow-up models 

ANOVAs will be run to assess the differences between student groups. Students will be divided in half based on reported levels of support. The two groups will be compared based on outcome variables of satisfaction of life, performance, emotion regulation, purpose, fear of failure, performance-based identity. 

Students who indicate they are athletes will be compared to non-athletes along the study's variables. 

Path Analysis and Structural equation modeling. Support variables (school, mother, father, coaches) will be included in both path and SEM models as independent variables. All other variables will be assessed as dependent variables. 

Mediation will be assessed using indirect effect models with 5,000 bootstrapped samples and bias-corrected 95% confidence intervals. Emotion regulation, fear of failure, and performance-based identity will be included as mediations within the model between sources of support and all other study variables.

q20.value: We do not anticipate needing transformation of data, but if necessary, we will transform skewed data using conventional techniques (e.g., log transformation). We plan on using untransformed variables, with the following exception: Outliers (+/- 3.29 SD from the mean) will be Winsorized to the nearest value that is not an outlier.

q21.value: We will use a two-tailed p-value of .05 as the threshold for significance. Effect sizes and confidence intervals will be reported. Because we have only one primary outcome variable (self-reported meaning), we do not plan on using adjustments for multiple comparisons.

q22.value:
We will exclude respondents who meet at least one of the following criteria:
- not being a student (e.g., a teacher who pilots the study)
- not being a student in the school assigned to us by Character Lab Research Network
- participating in multiple RCTs or pilots in the same session
- being enrolled in grade other than 9th, 10th, 11th, or 12th
- not matching school-provided data.

q23.value: We will use intent-to-treat (ITT) analyses and also examine and report evidence for selective attrition.

Teachers and administrators are committed to the success of their students but often lack detailed information into how they can best serve the whole student. Previous studies suggest that by targeting student engagement and well-being, then academic success will follow (Lewis, Huebner, Malone, & Valois, 2011; Lyons & Huebner, 2015; Suldo et al., 2011). Although this is likely an accurate conclusion, it is incomplete in directing school officials on how to improve student engagement and well-being. The results require clarification as to what types of external support are needed to facilitate various form
registration_responses.q4:
Students with higher levels of social support will have better well-being than those without social support. Higher levels of social support will be positively related to better academic outcomes.

Athletes will have higher levels of social support compared to non-athletic students. 

Emotion regulation abilities in students will be similar to the emotion regulation abilities of their parents. 

Emotion regulation will mediate the relationship between forms of social support and academic performance and well-being. 

Supportive school climate will be positively related to well-being variables (satisfaction with life, emotion regulation, purpose) and academic performance. A supportive school climate will be negatively related to the pressure to perform.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We expect a sample of more than 1000 participants.
registration_responses.q15: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above.
registration_responses.q20: We do not anticipate needing transformation of data, but if necessary, we will transform skewed data using conventional techniques (e.g., log transformation). We plan on using untransformed variables, with the following exception: Outliers (+/- 3.29 SD from the mean) will be Winsorized to the nearest value that is not an outlier.
registration_responses.q21: We will use a two-tailed p-value of .05 as the threshold for significance. Effect sizes and confidence intervals will be reported. Because we have only one primary outcome variable (self-reported meaning), we do not plan on using adjustments for multiple comparisons.
registration_responses.q22:
We will exclude respondents who meet at least one of the following criteria:
- not being a student (e.g., a teacher who pilots the study)
- not being a student in the school assigned to us by Character Lab Research Network
- participating in multiple RCTs or pilots in the same session
- being enrolled in grade other than 9th, 10th, 11th, or 12th
- not matching school-provided data.
registration_responses.q23: We will use intent-to-treat (ITT) analyses and also examine and report evidence for selective attrition.
registration_responses.q8.question: This is a cross-sectional survey study.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network(CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers. For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer tohttps://characterlab.org/research-network.
registration_responses.q17.question:
1. Satisfaction with life is measured with the Satisfaction with Life Scale. Diener, Emmons, Larsen, and Griffin (1985) developed the Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) to measure global satisfaction with life. 

2. Parental support, both mother and father, will be assessed using a 4-item parental support scale. It is used to assess perceived behaviors from mothers and fathers that communicate to the participant feelings of warmth, affection, and a sense of being valued (Bush, Peterson, Cobas, & Supple, 2002; Henry & Peterson, 1995; Peterson, Rollins, & Thomas, 1985). 

3. Non-parental support (coaches support) was measured with the 16-item Perceived Available Support in Sport Questionnaire (PASS-Q; Freeman, Coffee, & Rees, 2011). 

4. ERQ- Gross and John’s (2003) Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ) will be used to measure individual variation in emotion regulation. 

5. Student Assess Parental ERQ (Mother and Father)
Students will be asked to assess their parents' emotion regulation ability via Gross and John’s (2003) Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ). 

6. Fear of failure appraisal
A Performance Failure Appraisal Inventory (PFAI; Conroy, Willow, Metzler, 2010) will be used to assess the students' fear of failure. 

7. School Climate 
We will assess the quality of participants’ school environments using the following scale:  Student Perceptions of School Cohesion (Arrivallaga et al., 2009). This 10-item scale requires students to rate with a 5-point response scale their perceptions of the school social environment (e.g., “I feel a part of this school”)

8. Pressure to Perform
Participants will rate the degree to which they currently feel pressure to compete in sports and school. Ratings were made on separate 5-point scales (1 = no pressure; 5 = a lot of pressure). 

9. CESD
A screen for depression and other psychological disorders in adolescents (CESD; Garrison, Addy, Jackson, McKeown, Waller, 1991) was used to test for depressive symptoms. 

10. Purpose 
We will examine students' perspectives of purpose using the Claremont Purpose Scale (Bronk, Rcihes, Mangan, 2018). 

11. Performance-based identity scale 

In addition, Character Lab Research Network via the school will collect demographic data including age, gender, ethnicity, grade level, and SES indicators.
registration_responses.q19.question:
In general, models will be run without covariates. We may include demographic variables (e.g., gender, race/ethnicity) as covariates in follow-up models 

ANOVAs will be run to assess the differences between student groups. Students will be divided in half based on reported levels of support. The two groups will be compared based on outcome variables of satisfaction of life, performance, emotion regulation, purpose, fear of failure, performance-based identity. 

Students who indicate they are athletes will be compared to non-athletes along the study's variables. 

Path Analysis and Structural equation modeling. Support variables (school, mother, father, coaches) will be included in both path and SEM models as independent variables. All other variables will be assessed as dependent variables. 

Mediation will be assessed using indirect effect models with 5,000 bootstrapped samples and bias-corrected 95% confidence intervals. Emotion regulation, fear of failure, and performance-based identity will be included as mediations within the model between sources of support and all other study variables.
